isis.stitle: FULL POWER HYDRAULIC ABS BRAKE SYSTEM - REMOVE AND INSTALL - Low pressure hose

warning.para: The design and composition of the low pressure hose is critical. The low pressure hose must be replaced with the same design as installed by the manufacturer. The use of an incompatible hose assembly may cause system damage and loss of braking. Failure to follow this warning could result in property damage, personal injury or death.

caution.para: Individuals without factory training are advised not to work on the Full Power Brakes system to replace or repair items.

This is a modern, complex system offering greater braking proficiency and features than previous systems. If the system sustains damage or a component malfunctions and items need to be replaced, users are strongly advised to contact the nearest International dealer for professional assistance and repair. However, if location and circumstances prevent consulting the dealer, and components are to be replaced, the prescribed procedure must be followed accurately.

Precharged HCU's and spare parts must be handled with the appropriate care and attention and should not be exposed to excessive vibration or impact nor air being blown into the hydraulic ports prior to assembly to the vehicle.

step1.para: Install wheel chocks.

Set the ignition key to OFF and remove the two 30 Amp fuses (A3 and A4) that provide power to the brake system motors. The fuses are in the Power Distribution Center (PDC) located near the master cylinder (refer to FIGURE 32).
Connect the EZ-TECH ® to the diagnostic connector located under the instrument panel just left of the steering column. Set the ignition key to ON, start the EZ-TECH ® and open the TOOLBOX™ program.
Depressurize the system as follows:

step2.para: Depress the brake pedal a minimum of 30 times.
Use the EZ-TECH ® and TOOLBOX™ to verify that pressure at both accumulators is at 0 psi.

warning.para: Batteries expel explosive gases. Keep sparks, flames, burning cigarettes, or other ignition sources away at all times. Always wear safety glasses and a face shield when working near batteries to prevent personal injury.

step1.para: Set the ignition key to OFF and disconnect the battery negative cable (including the ECM ground cable).
Carefully clean the outside of the Hydraulic Compact Unit (HCU) and the Master Cylinder (MC) reservoir assembly.
Clean the area of the crossmember that the low pressure hose passes over, and the clamps that secure the hose to the chassis. Refer to FIGURE 37.

figure.caption: Figure 37. Low Pressure Hose from Master Cylinder to HCU

step1.para: Remove the clamp securing the low pressure hose to the MC bracket. Refer to FIGURE 33 . Retain the clamp, nut, and bolt.

figure.caption: Figure 38. Clamping the Low Pressure Hose

step1.para: Use a clamp to pinch the low pressure hose at the inlet to the HCU reservoir. Place the clamp midway between the HCU reservoir inlet and the crossmember, being careful not to damage the reservoir inlet. In some vehicle applications the rubber section of the low pressure hose is too short to provide a leakproof clamp at this location. If necessary, clamp the low pressure hose 4 or 5 inches below the master cylinder outlet. Refer to FIGURE 38 .
Remove the clamps (see FIGURE 37) securing the middle section of the low pressure hose to the chassis. Note the clamp positions to assist installation of new hose.

note.para: Before performing the following step, position a container to collect any drained or spilled brake fluid to ensure that no fluid will spill onto the ground or damage the paint. In the next 4 steps up to 3.4 liters (1 gal) of brake fluid will be drained.

step1.para: Disconnect the low pressure hose from the HCU reservoir.
Plug the low pressure hose and the reservoir inlet to prevent system contamination.
Verify that the container is positioned to catch fluid rapidly draining from the hose.

Remove the cap on the MC reservoir and the pinch clamp from the top of the low pressure hose. Remove the plug from the low pressure hose, and carefully open the clamp on the bottom of the hose. The fluid remaining in the MC reservoir and the low pressure hose will drain into the container.
Disconnect the hose from the MC reservoir. Plug the reservoir port. Plug the hose to prevent leakage during removal.
Remove the hose from the vehicle.

caution.para: To prevent contamination of the system, keep the ends of the replacement hose sealed until you are ready to connect them.

important.para: In the following step, position the hose clamps at the MC reservoir outlet and the HCU reservoir inlet so that the pinch tabs are easily accessible.

step1.para: Install the new hose. Make sure hose does not contact sharp edges, moving components or hot components.

step2.para: Connect the hose to the HCU reservoir and install clamp.
Connect the hose to the MC reservoir and install clamp.
Install the center clamps at the positions noted during removal.
Secure the low pressure hose to the MC bracket using the clamp, nut, and bolt removed earlier.

step1.para: Using new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container, fill the MC reservoir to the MAX mark. About 3.2 liters (0.9 gallons) are needed.
Connect the battery and install the two pump motor fuses.
Switch ON the ignition. The HCU pump motors will start and run for approximately 45 seconds. This will fill the accumulators and pressurize the system.
Verify that the fluid level in the MC reservoir is at the MAX mark.
Remove the two pump motor fuses.

Decrease pressure in the system by applying the brake pedal a minimum of 30 times. This will force fluid from the accumulators back into the HCU reservoir to purge trapped air from the reservoir, through the low pressure hose.
Install the two pump motor fuses.
Switch ON the ignition. The pump motors will start and run for approximately 45 seconds. This will fill the accumulators, pressurizing the system.
Pump the brakes rapidly 4 times to activate both HCU pump motors. After motors stop, fill the MC reservoir up to the MAX mark with new DOT 3 or DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container.

warning.para: If leakage is noted in the following step, the system MUST be depressurized BEFORE making repairs. Perform steps 2 thru 5 of the LOW PRESSURE HOSE REMOVAL procedures to verify that the system is depressurized. Failure to follow this warning could result in property damage, personal injury or death.

step1.para: Check system for leakage. If leakage is present, depressurize the system before making repairs.

Using the EZ-TECH ® and the TOOLBOX™ program clear all brake system related inactive fault codes. (Codes may have been set while disconnecting and reconnecting power to the system.) If active fault codes are indicated, refer to Section 5, DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING
to make the necessary repairs .
Disconnect the EZ-TECH ® from the diagnostic connector.
Remove wheel chocks.

para.emph: Further bleeding of the system is not necessary.
